title: 114_hr2899
content: The "Countering Violent Extremism Act of 2015" or the "CVE Act" authorizes the Office for Countering Violent Extremism within the Department of Homeland Security. The Office for Countering Violent Extremism in the Department of Homeland Security is established with the Assistant Secretary for Countering Violent Extremism appointed by the Secretary. Permanent staff with expertise in technical, media, communications, or marketing backgrounds will be assigned or hired for the Office. The Assistant Secretary for Countering Violent Extremism in the Department of Homeland Security appoints liaisons within various components and offices, including U.S. Customs and Border Protection, to support the Office for Countering Violent Extremism. Responsibilities include overseeing technical, media, communications, and marketing efforts. The Assistant Secretary for Countering Violent Extremism in the Department of Homeland Security coordinates activities to counter violent extremism, including identifying risk factors and populations targeted by violent extremism. The Assistant Secretary for Countering Violent Extremism in the Department of Homeland Security coordinates activities to counter violent extremism by identifying populations targeted by extremist propaganda, managing outreach to at-risk communities, ensuring research informs counter-extremism efforts, and developing a department-wide strategy. The Department of Homeland Security coordinates activities to counter violent extremism by developing a strategy that includes leveraging technology and social media platforms to counter extremist messaging. The Department of Homeland Security coordinates with various partners for counter-messaging activities, outreach, and cooperative agreements to counter violent extremism. The Department of Homeland Security focuses on countering violent extremism while respecting privacy and civil liberties. They develop metrics to evaluate programs and recommend research requirements in consultation with key officials. The Department of Homeland Security focuses on countering violent extremism by disseminating information and methods to practitioners and partners, assessing extremist propaganda methods, and establishing a counter-messaging program. The Department of Homeland Security focuses on countering violent extremism by disseminating information and methods to practitioners and partners, assessing extremist propaganda methods, and establishing a counter-messaging program. This program includes crafting strategic counter-messages using relevant Internet and social media platforms, and coordinating activities with other Federal departments and agencies. The Department of Homeland Security coordinates with other agencies on international countering violent extremism issues and provides guidance on grant usage for this purpose. The Assistant Secretary for Countering Violent Extremism coordinates with the Federal Emergency Management Agency to administer a grant program related to countering violent extremism. A memorandum of understanding outlines their roles in the administration of grants for this purpose. The Assistant Secretary for Countering Violent Extremism, in coordination with FEMA and the Officer for Civil Rights and Civil Liberties, establishes a grant program for community groups to create counter-messaging campaigns against violent extremism. The Secretary for Countering Violent Extremism, FEMA Administrator, and Officer for Civil Rights and Civil Liberties will provide an implementation plan for a grant program to the House and Senate Homeland Security Committees. The plan will include eligibility and application criteria, grant award methodology, and monitoring and evaluation procedures. The Assistant Secretary for Countering Violent Extremism will submit an annual report to Congress for the next five fiscal years, detailing the Office's activities. The Assistant Secretary for Countering Violent Extremism will submit annual reports to Congress on the Department's programs, policies, budget, and staffing for countering violent extremism in the United States. The Assistant Secretary for Countering Violent Extremism will provide Congress with an annual report detailing funding, activities, outcome metrics, and partnerships related to countering violent extremism. The annual report to Congress will include a summary of outreach organizations, grants awarded, training, personnel and funding needs, adaptation to threat environment, and considerations for civil rights and civil liberties. The annual report to Congress will include a summary of outreach organizations, grants awarded, training, personnel, funding needs, adaptation to threat environment, and considerations for civil rights and civil liberties, as well as an evaluation of the grant program's effectiveness in countering violent extremism and lessons learned from other departments and agencies. The term "violent extremism" is defined as ideologically motivated terrorist activities. $10,000,000 is authorized for the Office for Countering Violent Extremism annually from 2016 to 2020, with $6,000,000 allocated for the grant program. This section will terminate five years after enactment. The table of contents in the Act is amended to include a new item after section 103. The table of contents in the Act is amended to include a new item after section 103, which is the creation of the Office for Countering Violent Extremism under section 104.
